issues.description: Return type mismatch for messageOnFeed(): the problem statement (UML) specifies messageOnFeed() returns String, but the solution's Animal.java declares messageOnFeed() to return FeedResponse. This changes the core contract students must implement: they will expect to implement a method that returns a String (as described in the task and example song printing), whereas the solution forces a custom FeedResponse type. This is a structural conflict that will confuse students about the required method signature and return type.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the messageOnFeed() contract consistent with the problem statement. Either (A) change the solution to use String as the return type everywhere: modify Animal.java to declare public abstract String messageOnFeed(), change Pig and Seal to return String ("Oink!", "Arf Arf!"), and remove the FeedResponse class; or (B) update the problem statement and UML to specify a FeedResponse return type and document the FeedResponse class and its semantics. Prefer option (A) to preserve the exercise description.

issues.description: Inner-solution inconsistency: Goat.java implements messageOnFeed() returning String while Animal.java declares messageOnFeed() returning FeedResponse. This produces a compile-time incompatibility (Goat does not correctly override the abstract method) and is therefore an implementation error in the solution repository that will block compilation and confuse students who compare the solution to the specification.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the solution so all subclasses match the abstract method's signature. Either change Goat.messageOnFeed() to return FeedResponse (construct and return a FeedResponse) to match Animal, or (preferably) change the Animal abstract signature to return String and update Pig and Seal to return String as well. Ensure all subclasses use the same return type so code compiles and the design matches the problem statement.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual specification) defines Animal.messageOnFeed() as returning a String (messageOnFeed():String) and the template expects to print those String messages in the farm song/feeding methods. The solution repository instead introduces a new class FeedResponse and changes the abstract method signature to return FeedResponse (Animal.messageOnFeed():FeedResponse) while Pig and Seal return FeedResponse instances. This introduces a new identifier (FeedResponse) for the same conceptual "feed message" entity the problem describes as a String. The discrepancy changes the expected method signature and name-level contract students must implement and therefore creates a mapping barrier between the problem UML, the starter code expectations, and the provided solution.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the representation of the "feed message" consistent across artifacts. Two practical fixes (choose one):

1) Align the solution with the problem/template: change Animal.messageOnFeed() to return String, remove or stop using FeedResponse for this contract, and have Pig/Seal/Goat return the specified String messages (e.g. "Oink!", "Arf Arf!", "Maah!"). Update solution code: Animal.java -> public abstract String messageOnFeed(); Pig/Seal -> return String; remove FeedResponse class if unused.

2) If FeedResponse is desired for pedagogical reasons, update the problem statement/UML and the template to declare messageOnFeed():FeedResponse and document the FeedResponse fields (message, satisfied). Update template examples and instructions so students expect and can use FeedResponse (and ensure all solution classes consistently return FeedResponse).
